summary: This document is an email chain from April 2019 between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing significant frustration and delays in obtaining the FBI's scanned case file on Jeffrey Epstein from the FBI's Information Management Division. It reveals internal bureaucratic obstacles in the investigation.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: Author of the initial email in the chain, coordinating efforts to obtain FBI case files on Epstein from the Information Management Division.

events.title: Initial FBI Records Request
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office initially requested scanned records from the FBI's Epstein case file more than two months prior to April 2019.

events.title: Discussion to Elevate FBI Records Issue
events.description: Prosecutors discuss the need to elevate their request for FBI Epstein case files due to hitting a 'complete brick wall' with the FBI's Information Management Division.

keyFacts: Prosecutors were experiencing major delays in obtaining the FBI's scanned Epstein case file, having requested it over two months prior with no success.
The FBI's Information Management Division was unresponsive, with 'at least a dozen other unreturned emails and phone calls since January.'
The email chain indicates the FBI case file contained a substantial volume of material, referenced as 16,000 to 29,000 pages.
The correspondence shows internal frustration within the U.S. Attorney's Office and a need to 'elevate' the issue to higher authority to overcome bureaucratic obstacles.
